Mixed Boolean-Arithmetic (Part 3): Binary Permutation Polynomials

April 24, 2023

In this post we are going to find polynomials p,qâˆˆZnâ€‹[X], such that p(q(x))=x, where n=2w is a power of two. In particular, this means that p is invertible (bijective) and q=pâˆ’1 is its inverse, which makes them permutations of Znâ€‹.

Polynomials modulo a power of two are called Binary Polynomials, and the ones that permute the integers modulo 2w are called Binary Permutation Polynomials.

Most of the results in this post can actually be generalized to polynomials modulo a prime power pm and most of the papers referenced do so. Before we get into a classification, we will begin with some preparations.

The ring Znâ€‹[X]

Some of the nice properties of polynomials that we know from R[X] or C[X] are no longer true. Obviously Znâ€‹[X] is infinite (e.g. {1,X,X2,â€¦} is an infinite subset) but there are only nn (i.e. finitely many) functions Znâ€‹â†’Znâ€‹ and only n! permutations of Znâ€‹.

So there exist polynomials f,g with fî€ =g but f(x)=g(x)Â âˆ€xâˆˆZnâ€‹. To rephrase, there are polynomials that are different as expressions, i.e. have different coefficients, but compute the same function. Equivalently, there exist h=fâˆ’g such that hî€ =0 but h(x)=0Â âˆ€xâˆˆZnâ€‹. An example of this where n=16=24 is h(x)=8x2+8x. We will characterize all such polynomials later. This can never happen in C,R,Z, or generally in infinite UFDs as a consequence of Gauss's Lemma. In finite fields, by the same argument as above, this also happens, but only if âˆcâˆˆFqâ€‹â€‹(xâˆ’c) divides the polynomial, whereas it is more subtle in Znâ€‹ which is ultimately a result of the existence of zero divisors.

For now though, we see that it makes sense to differentiate between the polynomial expressions and the functions they induce. From now on, I will use uppercase letters for the polynomial expressions P,QâˆˆZnâ€‹[X] and lowercase letters for the corresponding polynomial functions p,qâˆˆPFnâ€‹ where PFnâ€‹ is the set of all functions Znâ€‹â†’Znâ€‹ that can be represented by polynomials. There is also the obvious ring-homomorphism Ï†:Znâ€‹[X]â†’PFnâ€‹:Pâ†¦p. By definition of PFnâ€‹, Ï† is surjective. Over R or C, Ï† is a bijection, so differentiating between the expressions and function doesn't really matter.

Some immediate questions are:

  • Are all functions Znâ€‹â†’Znâ€‹ in PFnâ€‹, i.e. is every function representable by a polynomial?
  • Is every permutation representable by a polynomial?

The answer two both questions is no in general. We will see that during proof of the characterization of binary permutation polynomials. Both are true if and only if n is a prime number (or 1). The next question then is, how many functions are representable by polynomials. We will find the answer for Binary Polynomials. You can find a discussion of the general case in [1] or [2].

It is often advantageous to consider polynomials FâˆˆZ[X] instead, and ask whether F is a permutation polynomial mod n, because we can (for example) talk about different moduli for the same polynomial, and I will often switch between these points of view without mentioning it, because it is very natural and shouldn't cause any confusion. There are however some instances where this makes some minor differences, e.g. when talking about the polynomials which evaluate to zero. In Znâ€‹[X] the only such polynomial of degree less than two is the zero polynomial, but in Z[X], for every kâˆˆZ the constant polynomials F=kn and linear polynomials F=knX are different polynomials which all evaluate to zero mod n.

Structure of the Post

In the next section, we will prove the characterization of binary permutation polynomials, which also provides an intuition on how restricted polynomials in Znâ€‹[X] are. Afterwards, we will try to find all polynomials that evaluate to zero, but before we can do that, we need to discuss polynomial division. Finally, we will try to find the inverse of a permutation polynomial, and see three different algorithms to achieve that. I came up with one myself and it has (as far as I know) not been published. It is the slowest (but in my opinion still practical ğŸ˜‰, though you should use one of the other two).

Characterization of Binary Permutation Polynomials

As I mentioned in the first post in this series, the first explicit characterization of binary permutation polynomials was given by Rivest in [3]. It's an elementary proof and easy to read, but he mentions that after the fact Mullen told him of a more general lemma that is already present in [2], which can also be used to derive the same characterization. We will follow Rivest's proof here (at times word for word), as we will need some of the results we prove along the way later, when trying to find a polynomial for the inverse permutation. I originally was not gonna give a complete proof here, (were it not for the intermediary results we will need later), and only used Hensel's Lemma (from which Mullen's lemma easily follows) to derive the same characterization, which I didn't want to simply discard, so you can find it here.

We will consider a polynomial P=a0â€‹+â‹¯+adâ€‹XdâˆˆZ[X]. Rivest's proof works by reducing the question of whether P is a permutation polynomial mod 2w to the case w=1. However, there are certain conditions on this, as we will see. We will start with the base case n=2 (w=1).

Lemma 1P is a permutation polynomial mod 2 if and only if (a1â€‹+a2â€‹+â€¦) is odd.
Proof: Of course p(0)=a0â€‹(mod2). So we need p(1)=a0â€‹+a1â€‹+â€¦=!1âˆ’a0â€‹(mod2). Adding a0â€‹ to both sides (or subtracting it, as they are equivalent mod 2) we get the Lemma.

We will now try to find conditions under which a permutation polynomial mod 2 is also a permutation polynomial mod 2w. This will work inductively by going from 2w to 2w+1 and the other way around. We will need some auxiliary Lemmas for it.

Lemma 2If P is a permutation polynomial mod n=2m=2w, then a1â€‹ is odd.
Proof: If a1â€‹ was even, then p(0)=p(m)(modn), which follows easily by computation.

The next Lemma will heavily restrict the class of permutations that can be represented by polynomials.

Lemma 3If P is a permutation polynomial mod n=2m=2w, then it is also a permutation polynomial mod m.
Notice that for general permutations, this absolutely doesn't have to be the case: Let w=2 and consider the permutation Ïƒ that swaps 0 and 3 and fixes 1 and 2. â€‹Ïƒ(0)=3Ïƒ(1)â€‹=1=1â€‹(mod2)(mod2)â€‹ So Ïƒ is not a permutation mod 2. Nevertheless, this has to be true for polynomials:

Of course p(x+m)=p(x)(modm), because x+m and x are just two representatives for x mod m. If p was not a permutation mod m, then there are two distinct values x and xâ€² such that p(x)=p(xâ€²)=y(modm). This means that there are four values {x,x+m,xâ€²,xâ€²+m} mod n that p maps to a value congruent to y mod m. But there are only two values congruent to y mod n.

Lemma 4If P is a permutation polynomial mod n=2m=2w, then P(x+m)=P(x)+m(modn), for all xâˆˆZnâ€‹.
Proof: As discussed before, p(x+m)=p(x)(modm). So if one maps to c mod n the other has to map to c+m mod n. So the difference between them will always be m mod n, which is another way to read the Lemma.

The next Lemma shows us, under which condition we can lift a permutation polynomial mod 2w to one mod 2w+1.

Lemma 5Let n=2m=2w with w>1. If P is a permutation polynomial mod m, then it is a permutation polynomial mod n if and only if (a3â€‹+a5â€‹+a7â€‹+â€¦) is even.
Proof: Since p(x+m)=p(x)(modm) and since P is a permutation polynomial mod m, the only way P could fail to be a permutation polynomial mod n would be if p(x+m)=p(m)(modn) for some x. So our next step is evaluating p(x+m)(modn). In order to do that, we will have to compute (x+m)i. Using the binomial theorem, it is easy to see that all terms with xiâˆ’j where j>1 are zero, so we are left with (x+m)i=xi+imxiâˆ’1(modn) for iâ‰¥1. Including the coefficient aiâ€‹ we have aiâ€‹(x+m)i=aiâ€‹xi+aiâ€‹imxiâˆ’1(modn) Usually the latter term will vanish and it will just be equal to aiâ€‹xi(modn), but when aiâ€‹ is odd and either
  • i=1 or
  • i>1 and both x and i are odd

it will be equal to aiâ€‹xi+m(modn).

In the case that i=1, we know from Lemma 2 that a1â€‹ is odd, so a1â€‹(x+m)=a1â€‹x+m(modn). For even x, by the above, this is the only m that we get in the evaluation of p(x+m), so p(x+m)=p(x)+m(modn). For odd x, we get an m from every odd i as well, as long as aiâ€‹ is odd. If aiâ€‹ is even aiâ€‹m=0(modn), so we can simply write p(x+m)=p(x)+(a1â€‹+a3â€‹+a5â€‹+â€¦)m(modn). Since a1â€‹ is odd, we have p(x+m)=p(x)+m(modn) if and only if (a3â€‹+a5â€‹+â€¦) is even.

Now, we can prove the main result.

Theorem: Characterization of Binary Permutation Polynomials
A polynomials P=a0â€‹+â‹¯+adâ€‹XdâˆˆZ[X] is a permutation mod 2w (w>1) if and only if
  • a1â€‹ is odd
  • a2â€‹+a4â€‹+a6â€‹+â€¦ is even
  • a3â€‹+a5â€‹+a7â€‹+â€¦ is even
Proof:
â‡’
If P is a permutation polynomial mod n, then a1â€‹ is odd by Lemma 2. By Lemma 3, P is also a permutation polynomial mod n/2 and by Lemma 5 (a3â€‹+a5â€‹+a7â€‹+â€¦) is even. By repeated application of Lemma 3, P is a permutation polynomial mod 2, and so (a1â€‹+a2â€‹+a3â€‹+â€¦) is odd by Lemma 1. Subtracting what we know from previous results, (a2â€‹+a4â€‹+a6â€‹+â€¦) is even.

â‡
If a1â€‹ is odd, (a2â€‹+a4â€‹+a6â€‹+â€¦) is even, and (a3â€‹+a5â€‹+a7â€‹+â€¦) is even, then P is a permutation polynomial mod n=2w, by induction on w, using Lemma 1 for the base case and Lemma 5 for the inductive step.

We will now concern ourselves with trying to find an inverse. But before we can do that, we need to find the polynomials that evaluate to zero, and before we can do that, we need to talk about polynomial division.

Polynomial Division and Zeros

Usually, polynomial division is only defined when the coefficients are in a field, but it is possible to define a limited version of polynomial division when the coefficients are in any commutative ring.

Theorem: (Limited) Polynomial Division
Let C be a commutative ring, F,GâˆˆC[X] and let the leading coefficient of G be a unit. Then there exist unique polynomials Q,RâˆˆC[X], such that F=GQ+R and degR<degG.
Of note is that the leading coefficient has to be a unit (which is trivially satisfied in a field). For example, you can't divide X2 by 2X in Z[X].

The proof is straightforward using the usual polynomial division algorithm. Let a,b be the leading coefficients of F,G respectively. To eliminate the leading coefficient a of F we multiply G by bâˆ’1a, so that the product also has a leading coefficient a, and subtract the result from F. The degree of F is now smaller and we can continue recursively.

Using polynomial division we can now prove the following.

TheoremLet C be a commutative ring. aâˆˆC is a root of FâˆˆC[X], i.e. f(a)=0, if and only if (Xâˆ’a)âˆ£F, i.e. there exists QâˆˆC[X], such that F=(Xâˆ’a)â‹…Q.
â‡
F=(Xâˆ’a)â‹…Q, so obviously f(a)=(aâˆ’a)q(a)=0.

â‡’
Using polynomial division by (Xâˆ’a), we can write F=(Xâˆ’a)Q+R, where Q,RâˆˆC[X] and degR<1, so R is a constant. We know f(a)=0, but on the other hand f(a)=(aâˆ’a)Q+R=R, so R=0 and we have F=(Xâˆ’a)Q or in other words (Xâˆ’a)âˆ£F.

This is, of course, what you would expect, but it is good to be aware that polynomial division can't always be done in commutative rings.

Functional Equivalence in Znâ€‹[X]

We will now deal with the problem of deciding when two polynomials represent the same function, as we will need it for the computation of the inverse. Equivalently, our problem is to find all polynomials F that evaluate to 0, i.e. f(x)=0 for all x. In the language of homomorphisms, we are searching for kerÏ† which is an ideal. Remember that Ï† is the homomorphism mapping polynomial expressions to functions. We will call this ideal the zero idealnil:=kerÏ† Note that this deviates from the usual meaning of "zero ideal", which is the boring ideal {0}. By the (first) isomorphism theorem, PFnâ€‹â‰…Znâ€‹[X]/nil, which means we can uniquely represent a polynomial function by representatives that we will later call "reduced polynomials". Of course, nil is infinite (every non-zero ideal in Znâ€‹[X] is), but by Hilbert's basis theorem, it is finitely generated, so what we really want, is a set of generators.

Theorem: Vanishing Binary Polynomials
Let PâˆˆZnâ€‹[X]. p=0 if and only if Pâˆˆ(P0â€‹,â€¦,Pdâ€‹)=nil, where d is the smallest integer such that nâˆ£d!, and Piâ€‹=gcd(n,i!)nâ€‹j=0âˆiâˆ’1â€‹(Xâˆ’j) Additionally, P2â€‹,P4â€‹,â€¦,Pdâ€‹ is a minimal generating set for nil.

This might seems complicated at first, but why these evaluate to zero is actually rather intuitive, once you understand what is going on. I've seen two ways of proving this. Singmaster [1] sets up a clever induction. This is in my opinion the more elementary proof so I suggest you check it out if you want to see a proof. In the Appendix he mentions a different way of proving this using the Newton "series" (it is a finite sum for polynomials). [2] also follows this approach.

To get some understanding of these polynomials and why they evaluate to zero we will consider polynomials of degree less than three. Let FâˆˆZnâ€‹[X] evaluate to zero, that is f(x)=0 for all xâˆˆZnâ€‹. It is relatively easy to see that the only such polynomial of degree less than 2 is F=0. Let's think through the case degF=2. An idea you might have, is that since (Xâˆ’a)âˆ£F for all x, the product Xâ‹…(Xâˆ’1)â‹…â€¦â‹…(Xâˆ’n+1)âˆ£F But this can't be true for degree reasons alone, e.g. 8X2+8X evaluates to zero mod 16 but the product has degree 16. We know that f(0)=f(1)=0, so Xâˆ£Fand(Xâˆ’1)âˆ£F As before, a priori this doesn't mean X(Xâˆ’1)âˆ£F, but in this case it actually is true. Since Xâˆ£F, we can write F=XQ. We know f(1)=0, but on the other hand f(1)=1â‹…q(1), so q(1)=0, which implies (Xâˆ’1)âˆ£Q. So overall we can write F=câ‹…Xâ‹…(Xâˆ’1) We now have to find all c such that f evaluates to zero. We know that the product X(Xâˆ’1) will be even, since one of the factors is even. It is either zero, in which case any c is okay, or in the "worst case" two (for x=2). So it suffices to choose c=2nâ€‹. F=2nX(Xâˆ’1)â€‹=2nâ€‹X2+2nâ€‹X This is the definition of P2â€‹ in the theorem above! Generalizing this logic to higher degrees to see that all polynomials that evaluate to zero are indeed generated by the Piâ€‹ is not straightforward but also not too difficult. Again, see the induction in [1].

What we can do, is understand the definition of Piâ€‹ better, and see why those polynomials indeed evaluate to zero. Let's think about the product Xâ‹…(Xâˆ’1)â‹…â€¦â‹…(Xâˆ’i+1) in the definition of Piâ€‹ in Z instead of Znâ€‹. Note that I will sweep various details under the rug here, as they just distract from the core idea, but rest assured, they can be fixed relatively easily. Plugging in any value c for X, it will be the product of i consecutive numbers, which we can write as (câˆ’i)!c!â€‹=(icâ€‹)i! so it is divisible by i!. (The product of i consecutive integers is always divisible by i!). In the "worst case" the product is i! itself.

What we want to do now, is multiply that product by something, that makes the result zero mod n, i.e. such that the result is a multiple of n. If we want the smallest factor that is sufficient, we want the result to be the least common multiple of n and i!. By the identity lcm(a,b)â‹…gcd(a,b)=aâ‹…b for natural numbers a, b, we can find the factor gcd(n,i!)nâ€‹ that you can see in the definition of Piâ€‹.

What I haven't seen mentioned anywhere, is that the resulting generating set is not minimal. This is only really useful in that it allows you to save some memory. P0â€‹=n and P1â€‹=nX both of which are zero mod n, so they can be removed. These polynomials are included when considering polynomials over Z which evaluate to zero mod n.

But these are not the only ones. Let i<d be an even integer. We want to show that Pi+1â€‹ redundant. The leading coefficients of Piâ€‹ and Pi+1â€‹ are the same, since i is even and i+1 is odd, gcd(2w,i!)=gcd(2w,(i+1)!). Calling the leading coefficient c, we can factor Pi+1â€‹: Pi+1â€‹=cj=0âˆiâ€‹(Xâˆ’j)=(Xâˆ’i)(cj=0âˆiâˆ’1â€‹(Xâˆ’j))=(Xâˆ’i)Piâ€‹ Thus Pi+1â€‹âˆˆ(Piâ€‹), i.e. Pi+1â€‹ is generated by Piâ€‹.

All in all, for odd i, Piâ€‹ is superfluous and we have nil=(P2â€‹,P4â€‹,â€¦,Pdâ€‹)

This generating set is minimal, because the coefficient of the leading term is strictly decreasing as the degree increases, since gcd(2w,(i+2)!)>gcd(2w,i!).

Reduced Polynomials

Similar to how there is a (in some sense) good way to choose representatives in Z/nZ as 0,â€¦,nâˆ’1, the same is true for PFnâ€‹â‰…Znâ€‹[X]/nil. The reason is that we want to do computations on these polynomials and want the representation to be small. This means that the degree and the coefficients should be as small as possible.

Let F=a0â€‹+â‹¯+aeâ€‹xeâˆˆZ[X] and let d,P0â€‹,â€¦,Pdâ€‹ be the ones from the theorem on vanishing binary polynomials above. We can always find an equivalent polynomial G with degG<d. Notice that the leading coefficient of Pdâ€‹ is 1, so we can eliminate the coefficient aiâ€‹ of F where iâ‰¥d by multiplying Pdâ€‹ by aiâ€‹Xdâˆ’i and subtracting the result from F.

We can reduce the other coefficients of F in a similar way. Let liâ€‹ be the leading coefficient of Piâ€‹, i.e.liâ€‹=gcd(n,i!)nâ€‹ which is a power of two. We can reduce the coefficient aiâ€‹ into the range 0â‰¤aiâ€‹<liâ€‹ by multiplying Piâ€‹ by âŒŠliâ€‹aiâ€‹â€‹âŒ‹ and subtracting the result from F.

Theorem: Reduced Binary Polynomials
Let FâˆˆZ[X] and let d be the smallest integer such that nâˆ£d!. There exists a unique polynomial G=a0â€‹+â‹¯+adâˆ’1â€‹xdâˆ’1âˆˆZ[X] that computes the same function mod n, i.e. f(x)=g(x)(modn), with0â‰¤aiâ€‹<gcd(n,i!)nâ€‹

This also allows us to count the number of functions that can be represented by polynomials.

Theorem: Number of distinct Polynomials Functions/Permutations
The number of distinct polynomial functions mod n isâˆ£PFnâ€‹âˆ£=i=0âˆdâˆ’1â€‹gcd(n,i!)nâ€‹ The number of permutations that can be represented by polynomials is8âˆ£PFnâ€‹âˆ£â€‹

The first part follows from the theorem on reduced binary polynomials. By the Characterization of Binary Permutation Polynomials, aiâ€‹ has to be odd, which excludes half of the functions. The sums a2â€‹+a4â€‹+â€¦ and a3â€‹+a5â€‹+â€¦ have to be even which exclude half again respectively, so overall an eighth of the polynomial functions are permutations.

These are only tiny fractions of the number of possible functions and permutations.

When we discuss the inversion of permutation polynomials next, consider all computations on polynomials (e.g. their composition) to include reducing the result with at least Pdâ€‹ so that the degree doesn't explode. We can also quickly bound d=d(n) in terms of n=2w, which will be useful to determine the complexity of algorithms. d was defined to be the smallest integer such that nâˆ£d!. It is easy to see that dâ‰¤2w, since (2w)! is the product of w even numbers (and w odd numbers). Thus n=2wâˆ£(2w)!. In particular d(n)=O(w).

In the cases we care about the most, w itself is also a power of two, e.g. 8, 16, 32, 64. In those cases d=w+2. Consider how many times 2 divides w!=2c!. For every even number greater than zero and not greater than w, there is a factor of 2. Similarly for every multiple of 4, we get another factor of 2, and so on. There are 2câˆ’1 such even numbers, 2câˆ’2 such multiplies of 4, and so on. So overall, 2c! has exactly 20+21+â‹¯+2câˆ’1=2câˆ’1 factors of 2. But we wanted 2c factors of two, i.e. an additional one, which (w+2)! obviously has.

Inverting Binary Permutation Polynomials

Let PâˆˆZnâ€‹[X] be a permutation polynomial. It is not immediately clear that the inverse permutation pâˆ’1 is even representable by a polynomial. To see that it is, consider the group of all permutations on n elements Snâ€‹. We have pâˆ’1=pmâˆ’1 where m is the order of p, i.e. the order of the subgroup generated by p, m=âˆ£âŸ¨pâŸ©âˆ£. Note that pn in this context isn't the product pâ‹…â€¦â‹…p, it is the composition pâˆ˜â€¦âˆ˜p. But pmâˆ’1 is representable by a polynomial, because the composition of polynomials is still a polynomial. This gives us an extremely inefficient algorithm to invert any permutation polynomial: We just compute p2,p3,p4,â€¦ in Z[X]/nil. When the result is the identity, we know that the polynomial in the last step was the inverse. The problem is of course that the order of the subgroup could be very big, e.g. âˆ£âŸ¨xâ†¦x+1âŸ©âˆ£=n and n could easily be 264 in practice.

However, we can turn this into a practical algorithm.

Inversion by Composition

Theorem: Order of Binary Permutation Polynomials
Let PâˆˆZ[X] be a permutation polynomial mod n=2w. Then the order of p mod n is a power of two, less than or equal to n, i.e.ordÂ p:=âˆ£âŸ¨pâŸ©âˆ£=2i where iâ‰¤w.
The converse of this theorem is not true, as the example Ïƒ in Lemma 3 has order 2, but does not have a polynomial representation as explained there.

The weaker version of this theorem (weaker bound on the order), follows from Lagrange's theorem and the fact that the number of distinct permutation polynomials is a power of two, as can be seen from the theorem on the number of distinct permutation polynomials mod n.

The proof will be by induction on w. For w=1, there are only two permutations, the identity of order one, and swapping 0 and 1, of order two. Let PâˆˆZ[X] be a permutation polynomial mod 2w with w>1. We know that P is also a permutation polynomial mod m=n/2 by Lemma 3. By the induction hypothesis, p has order 2i mod m where i<w. We have p2i(x)=x(modm) for all xâˆˆZmâ€‹. We will now try to figure out the order mod n. Fix an xâˆˆZmâ€‹. Let o be the smallest integer such that po(x)=x(modm), i.e. the length of the cycle containing x mod m. We know that o is a power of two and less than or equal to 2i, since the order of the permutation is both a power of two and the least common multiple of its cycles lengths.

We now have to distinguish between two cases mod n:

Suppose po(x)=x(modn). By Lemma 4, we know po(x+m)=x+m(modn). So po maps x and x+m to themselves. Obviously, there is no j<o such that pj(x)=x(modn) or pj(x+m)=x+m(modn), as that would contradict that o is the cycle length of x mod m.

Otherwise po(x)=x+m(modn). By Lemma 4, we know po(x+m)=x(modn). Thusp2o(x)=po(po(x))=po(x+m)=x(modn) Andp2o(x+m)=po(po(x+m))=po(x)=x+m(modn) As before, there is no j<o such that pj(x)=x+m(modn) or pj(x+m)=x(modn). There can also be no o<j<2o such that pj(x)=x(modn) or pj(x+m)=x+m(modn), since otherwise pj(x)=pjâˆ’o(po(x))=pjâˆ’o(x)=x(modm), which, again, contradicts that o is the cycle length of x mod m.

So the cycle length of x mod n has either stayed the same or doubled. And the cycle length of x+m mod n is the same as that of x. It now easily follows that the order of p mod n has either stayed the same or doubled. In either case, it is a power of two less than n.

Now, the idea is that f2w can be computed in w compositions instead of 2w, by using the associativity of function composition f2i=fiâˆ˜fi So the algorithm can compute f,f2,f4,f8,â€¦,f2i until the result is the identity, i.e. f2i(x)=x for all x. The inverse is then f2iâˆ’1, which can be computed like this f2iâˆ’1=fâˆ˜f2âˆ˜f4âˆ˜â‹¯âˆ˜f2iâˆ’1 Overall, this will take at most 2w compositions.

To implement the algorithm as presented, we would have to store f,f2,f4,â€¦ to do the composition at the end. The following algorithm avoids this, but otherwise follows the same idea.

# `f`: Permutation Polynomial
# `w`: Integer width (mod 2^w)
# Returns the inverse of `f`
def invert(f, w):
    # `inverse` will contain f, f^3, f^7, f^15, ..., f^(2^i-1)
    inverse = f
    for _ in range(0, w):
        # Compose `inverse` and `f`
        # This will be f^(2^i).
        g = reduce(compose(inverse, f), w)

        # If this is the identity then
        # f^(2^i-1) is the inverse.
        if g.is_identity():
            return inverse

        # Compose f^(2^i-1) and f^(2^i)
        # to get f^(2^(i+1)-1) for the
        # next iteration.
        inverse = reduce(compose(inverse, g), w)

Let's quickly look at the complexity when everything (composition, reduction, multiplication) is using the naive algorithm. We will consider additions and multiplications in Znâ€‹ to have unit cost. Composition Pâˆ˜Q is just evaluating P at Q which can be done using Horner's method with n multiplications (and additions). A multiplication and subsequent reduction by Pdâ€‹ is in O(d2). So the composition is in O(d3). Since d(n)=O(w), this is equivalent to O(w3). We have to do 2w compositions, so overall the asymptotic complexity of this algorithm is O(w4)=O((logn)4).

Inversion by Newton's Method

A different algorithm and - as far as I know - the first general algorithm [4] was published in 2016. It is based on Newton's method. Take the following as intuition, not as proof, we will do a lot of things that shouldn't work and barely make sense. You could say, we are doing engineering maths ğŸ˜‰.

The usual step in Newton's method is xi+1â€‹=xiâ€‹âˆ’fâ€²(xiâ€‹)f(xiâ€‹)â€‹ where we are trying to approximate a root of f.

In our case, given an F we are trying to find G such that Fâˆ˜G=X. We can reformulate this as a root finding problem of F(G)âˆ’X where F(G) means evaluating F at G, i.e. the composition. We are treating G as a variable, i.e. the x here. Substituting this for f Gi+1â€‹=Giâ€‹âˆ’dGiâ€‹dâ€‹(F(Giâ€‹)âˆ’X)F(Giâ€‹)âˆ’Xâ€‹=Giâ€‹âˆ’Fâ€²âˆ˜Giâ€‹(Fâˆ˜Giâ€‹)âˆ’Xâ€‹ To evaluate the right-hand side, we need to invert Fâ€²âˆ˜Giâ€‹, which was our original problem. However, taking the derivative of (Fâˆ˜G)=X with respect to X, we get (Fâ€²âˆ˜Giâ€‹)â‹…Giâ€²â€‹=1. Dividing by Fâ€²âˆ˜Giâ€‹, we get Fâ€²âˆ˜Giâ€‹1â€‹=Giâ€²â€‹. So overall the step can be written as: Gi+1â€‹=Giâ€‹âˆ’Giâ€²â€‹â‹…((Fâˆ˜Giâ€‹)âˆ’X)

[4] cites some french paper for the proof that this will work, which I can't read. Maybe someone who knows some p-adic analysis can prove this. In particular, I think some generalization of Hensel's lemma can probably prove this.

Experimentally, this always finds a solution with G0â€‹=X. And the number of iterations is about log2â€‹w=log2â€‹log2â€‹n. If we trust this experimental observation, then the complexity would be O(w3logw)=O((logn)3loglogn).

Inversion by (Lagrange) Interpolation

The last technique we will look at is [5], but the idea of using interpolation was already presented in [4], where the authors couldn't quite make it work.

Let us try to naively apply Lagrange interpolation to find a polynomial based on sample points. We are not trying to invert anything yet, just doing interpolation. Formally, given distinct x1â€‹,â€¦,xmâ€‹âˆˆZnâ€‹ and any y1â€‹,â€¦,ymâ€‹âˆˆZnâ€‹, we are trying to find PâˆˆZnâ€‹[X] such that p(xiâ€‹)=yiâ€‹ for all 1â‰¤iâ‰¤m.

What you could try to do (the authors of [4] did this) is to construct the Lagrange basis polynomials liâ€‹(x)=1â‰¤jâ‰¤mjî€ =iâ€‹âˆâ€‹(xiâ€‹âˆ’xjâ€‹)(xâˆ’xjâ€‹)â€‹ The solution would then be p(x)=i=1âˆ‘mâ€‹yiâ€‹liâ€‹(x) The problem is that we can't compute the liâ€‹ because we have to invert the denominator which (aside from a few trivial cases) will always be even and thus not invertible.

We could have seen this a different way: If we could do standard Lagrange interpolation, we could find a polynomial representation for any function Znâ€‹â†’Znâ€‹, which is not possible, as not every function is representable by a polynomial.

There is, however, another formulation of the problem as a system of linear equations, which can be generalized from fields to the ring Znâ€‹ and lets us apply the results from Part 2.

I assume the idea is well-known, so I will go over it quickly. We have to choose the degree of the polynomial beforehand. Usually, (i.e. over a field), degP=mâˆ’1, as this results in a system with a unique solution, but in our case, we know that for any polynomial there is a reduced polynomial with degP<d, so we can always choose degP=dâˆ’1.

Note that even when m=n, i.e. the output for every input in Znâ€‹ is specified, we will not get a unique solution (if one exists), since we could add any polynomial in nil. On the other extreme, even if only two points on the polynomial are specified, there need not exist a polynomial of any degree that passes through these points: Let n=24=16,x1â€‹=0,y1â€‹=0,x2â€‹=8,y2â€‹=1. As we have seen before, p(x)=p(x+8)(mod8), so we can't have p(0)=0(mod16) and p(8)=1(mod16). This underlines the fact that linear algebra over rings is a lot weirder than over fields.

Moving on, what you do is construct the Vandermonde matrix V with Vi,jâ€‹=xijâˆ’1â€‹ and the vector y with yiâ€‹=yiâ€‹ and then solve Vx=y. The vector x will contain the coefficients of the polynomial, if the system has a solution. Note, that we need to solve this system in Znâ€‹ which was discussed in Part 2. The algorithms shown there give us an x as well as a basis for kerV. The elements of the (basis of the) kernel can of course also be treated as polynomials. They are a generating set for all polynomials that evaluate to 0 on the xiâ€‹, i.e. p(xiâ€‹)=0. Some of them will belong to the "zero ideal" kerÏ† that evaluate to zero everywhere, but there could also exist others which are non-zero for inputs not equal to any xiâ€‹. Differentiating between the two is easy, just reduce the polynomials. The coefficients of polynomials in the zero-ideal will be reduced to 0. By the way, the generating set will usually not be minimal, because we are effectively treating R[X] as an R-module here, meaning the coefficients of linear combinations are in R, whereas for the generating set, we treat R[X] as an R[X]-module.

Now, we are finally ready to look at the algorithm for inverting a permutation polynomial PâˆˆZnâ€‹[X].

  1. Compute xiâ€‹=p(i) for 0â‰¤i<d.
  2. Solve the interpolation problem q(xiâ€‹)=i by constructing and solving the linear system.
  3. Q is the/an inverse.

Once you look at it for a bit, you might think it's rather straightforward, but there is some subtlety to this. The intuitive explanation that is not quite correct is this: We are looking for a polynomial of degree dâˆ’1 meaning d coefficients, so we should have d sample points to find a unique polynomial. We want q(p(x))=x for all xâˆˆZnâ€‹, so plugging in the first d values, we get q(p(0))=0,â€¦,q(p(dâˆ’1))=dâˆ’1. So we can use p(0),â€¦,p(dâˆ’1) as the sample points.

The problem with this intuition is that half of it makes sense for polynomials over a field, while the other half only for polynomials over Znâ€‹. What we know for sure is that q(p(i))=i for 0â‰¤i<d. We still have to show that this also holds for iâ‰¥d, i.e. there is no solution to the linear system where this doesn't hold for all i. We know, there is one solution where this is true, when Q is an inverse of P, so we need to show that the kernel of the linear system kerV only contains polynomials in the "zero ideal". Polynomials F in the kernel satisfy f(i)=0 for 0â‰¤i<d. This means, we need to show that f(i)=0 for 0â‰¤i<d implies f(i)=0 for all iâˆˆZnâ€‹. I don't think there is an easier way to see this than to follow the proof that the Piâ€‹ generate the "zero ideal". In that proof you only need to use that f(i)=0 for 0â‰¤i<d to get the same generators, which are 0 everywhere.

TheoremA polynomial function fâˆˆPFnâ€‹ is uniquely determined by f(0),â€¦,f(dâˆ’1) where d is the smallest positive integer such that nâˆ£d!.

Note that given values y0â€‹,â€¦,ydâˆ’1â€‹, there is not necessarily a polynomial function fâˆˆPFnâ€‹ such that f(i)=yiâ€‹ for all i. For example for n=2w, we have f(x)=f(x+2)(mod2).

The authors of [5] took advantage of the special form of V to compute the LU-Decomposition which can be used to solve the linear system without needing to resort to a general algorithm for solving linear systems mod n. The complexity will also be better than that of the general algorithm. The general LU-Decomposition can also be used to show the uniqueness of the solution. The authors consider inversions to have unit cost, which I don't think is quite realistic, and come to the conclusion that the algorithm has quadratic complexity in w.

Conclusion

We've seen the most important theory on binary polynomials:

  • We have a characterization of binary permutation polynomials, which also allows us to generate random permutation polynomials.
  • We can decide when two binary polynomials compute the same function.
  • Given a binary permutation polynomial, we can efficiently find an inverse.

Appendix: Characterization of Binary Permutation Polynomials using Hensel's Lemma

Usually Hensel's Lemma is presented as a statement about lifting factorizations of polynomials mod p to factorizations mod pm. We will only need the special case of lifting roots:

Theorem: Hensel Lifting of Simple Roots
Let FâˆˆZ[X], p be a prime number and mâ‰¥1 an integer. If râˆˆZ is a simple root of f mod p, i.e. f(r)=0modpandfâ€²(r)î€ =0modp then there exists a unique sâˆˆZpmâ€‹, such that f(s)=0modpmandr=smodp

Now, let FâˆˆZ[X] be a polynomial. We need to rephrase the property of being a permutation polynomial in terms of roots: F is a permutation polynomial mod n if and only if (Fâˆ’c) has a single root for every câˆˆZnâ€‹. Or in other words, if there is a unique râˆˆZnâ€‹ such that f(r)=c for every câˆˆZnâ€‹. Using the Hensel's Lemma we can now find a condition on the polynomial mod p that implies the above.

Theorem: Classification of Permutation Polynomials modulo Prime Powers
Let FâˆˆZ[X], p be a prime, m>1. F is a permutation polynomial mod pm if and only if f is a permutation mod p and fâ€²(r)î€ =0modp for all râˆˆZpâ€‹.

The â‡ direction is relatively easy. Since F is permutation polynomial mod p, we know that Fâˆ’c has a single root mod p for câˆˆZpmâ€‹. Because (Fâˆ’c)â€²=Fâ€² and fâ€²(r)î€ =0 mod p, we can Hensel lift this root to exactly one mod pm. So Fâˆ’c also has a single root mod pm, which makes it a permutation of Zpmâ€‹.

We will prove the â‡’ direction by contradiction. Suppose F is not a permutation polynomial mod p, meaning there exists a câˆˆZpâ€‹ such that no xâˆˆZpâ€‹ is mapped to c via f. But since f(x+np)=f(x)modp, no element is ever mapped into the equivalence class of c ({c,c+p,â€¦}) mod pm, so the function is not a bijection.

Now suppose that f is a permutation mod p, but that fâ€²(c)=0 mod p, for some câˆˆZpâ€‹. We need to discuss what happens to repeated roots.

Theorem: Hensel Lifting of Repeated Roots
Let FâˆˆZ[X], p be a prime number and mâ‰¥1 an integer. If râˆˆZ is a repeated root of f mod p, i.e. f(r)=0modpandfâ€²(r)=0modp then there are either no, or at least p, sâˆˆZpmâ€‹, such that f(s)=0modpmandr=smodp

See Wikipedia's explanation for a proof. If there are no roots, then no value Zpmâ€‹ maps to c, otherwise there at least p values that map to c. In either case, it is not a permutation.

Notice that if a polynomial is a permutation polynomial mod pc with c>1, then it is a permutation polynomial mod pm for all mâˆˆN. In the special case of p=2, we already saw this before.

Let P=a0â€‹+â‹¯+adâ€‹XdâˆˆZ2wâ€‹[X]. For P to be a permutation, it needs to be a permutation on Z2â€‹. The following calculations will all be done in Z2â€‹. Of course p(0)=a0â€‹, so p(1)=1âˆ’a0â€‹ for p to be a permutation.

p(1)=a0â€‹+â‹¯+adâ€‹=!1âˆ’a0â€‹ So a1â€‹+â‹¯+adâ€‹=1, i.e. a1â€‹+â‹¯+adâ€‹ needs to be odd. Furthermore we need pâ€²(0)=1 and pâ€²(1)=1: pâ€²(x)=a1â€‹+2a2â€‹x+3a3â€‹x2+â€¦ pâ€²(0)=a1â€‹=!1 So a1â€‹ needs to be odd. pâ€²(1)=a1â€‹+a3â€‹+a5â€‹+â€¦=!1 So (a1â€‹+a3â€‹+a5â€‹+â€¦) needs to be odd as well. The characterization of Rivest now follows easily:

Theorem: Characterization of Binary Permutation Polynomials
A polynomials P=a0â€‹+â‹¯+adâ€‹XdâˆˆZ[X] is a permutation mod 2w (w>1) if and only if
  • a1â€‹ is odd
  • a2â€‹+a4â€‹+a6â€‹+â€¦ is even
  • a3â€‹+a5â€‹+a7â€‹+â€¦ is even
